III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation An agency worker was arrested by Genesse County Sheriffs on
2/28/2025 for taking money from a grandfather for foster case
served by the agency. The grandfather was reportedly giving the
worker money to pay for his daughter's rehab. He had been
giving the worker money since November. The elder task force
2

with the Genesee County Sheriff's Department caught the worker
taking $430.00 from the grandfather today. It appears that the
worker reportedly took approximately $20,000.00 over the past 5
months.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Director was interviewed via video conferencing on 3/24/2025.
She reported having received a call from Attorney, the Guardian
Ad Litem assigned to the case, reporting Relative A called
Attorney to let her know he had concerns with money he had been
giving Foster Care Worker 1. Attorney stated Relative A told her
he had been giving Foster Care Worker 1 money for “a while” and
Foster Care Worker 1 had asked him for over $20,000 during that
time. Director stated her understanding is that Foster Care Worker
1 told Relative A his daughter, the mother of the child in Relative
A’s care, was in a facility receiving substance abuse treatment in
Sault Ste. Marie. Foster Care Worker 1 told Relative A his
daughter was doing well in that facility, but the state would only
cover a portion of the cost for her to stay, and he needed to pay
the remaining cost. Foster Care Worker 1 also asked Relative A to
pay for a tv for his daughter as well as a computer so she could
enroll in school courses. Director’s understanding is that Relative
A’s daughter called him at which time he learned she was not in
Sault Ste. Marie, which raised his red flags.
Director stated Foster Care Worker 1 started at their agency as a
Case Aide while she completed her education. Once she earned
her degree, she became a foster care worker. Director stated the
agency had no concerns with her performance and multiple
families who knew her as a case aide requested her as their foster
care worker.
Licensee Designee was interviewed via video conferencing on
3/24/2025. She reported being in the administration building when
she received a call from Director on 2/28/2025 telling her she
needed to go to the program building. When she got there six
police officers were there with a warrant for Foster Care Worker
1’s work items. She stated she did not know why they were there,
but the search warrant indicated they were investigating fraud.
Licensee Designee stated the officers wanted documents and
electronic access related to all of Foster Care Worker 1’s cases,
not just the one named on the search warrant, so Licensee
Designee called the MDHHS Deputy Director who told her she
could provide the officers with everything they asked for. Licensee
Designee reported the officers didn’t say much to her, but they
asked her if there would be any reason Foster Care Worker 1
would take money from Caregiver A for Parent A.
3

License Designee reported not having prior concerns with Foster
Care Worker 1. She stated she had no suspicion of her acting
inappropriately.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed on 3/24/2025 via video
conferencing. She reported she was not working on 2/28/2025
when she received a call from Director who wanted to know where
Foster Care Worker 1 was because there were police at the
agency. Foster Care Supervisor checked Foster Care Worker 1’s
location using her iPhone which identified Foster Care Worker 1
as being at a local farmer’s market. Foster Care Supervisor was
not given any additional information on that day. On 3/4/2025
Foster Care Supervisor was copied in a group email which stated
Attorney had told Caregiver A to not let anyone into his home.
Attorney responded to that email indicating the case had been
reassigned to an MDHHS worker because Foster Care Worker 1
had been arrested for taking $20-25,000 from Caregiver A. Foster
Care Supervisor stated this was the first she had heard of the
allegations.
Foster Care Supervisor reported she had been directly assigned
to Youth A’s case until Foster Care Worker 1 took over. She
reported Caregiver A had offered her gas money in the past for
helping his daughter, but Foster Care Supervisor did not accept
any money. Foster Care Supervisor stated she does not know if
the agency has a written policy about not accepting money, but
she has had conversations with all the workers she supervises
about not accepting anything from caregivers.
Foster Care Supervisor reported she never had any concerns with
Foster Care Worker 1’s job performance. She stated Foster Care
Worker 1 would never strike her as someone who would do
something like she is alleged to have done. Foster Care
Supervisor has since called all the caregivers associated with
youths on Foster Care Worker 1’s caseload and no one has
reported anything about Foster Care Worker 1 taking money from
them.
Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed by phone on 3/25/2025.
She stated she went to court for this family on 2/19/2025 at which
time she requested termination of Parent A’s rights. A week later,
she was taken into custody by the police. She stated no charges
were filed so she was released. She stated the police took her
work phone and computer and she voluntarily gave them her
personal phone, personal iPad and access to her two bank
4

accounts. She stated she took two lie detector tests and passed
both, adding she drove an hour away and paid $850 for one of the
tests. She would not state why she was taken into custody and
would not answer whether she took anything from Caregiver A on
the advice of her attorney. She reported she has heard that the
people making accusations against her aren’t cooperating with the
investigation and are refusing to take lie detector tests, so the
allegations won’t be going anywhere.
Foster Care Worker 1 stated the agency has a policy that staff
cannot take anything from caregivers.
Foster Care Worker 2 was interviewed by phone on 3/25/2025.
She reported having worked a couple of desks down in the same
room as Foster Care Worker 1. She stated she would help Foster
Care Worker 1 with writing service plans and with court
preparation for Youth A’s case. She stated there was one court
hearing during which Foster Care Worker 1 testified she had
reached out to Parent A through social media, which Foster Care
Worker 2 found strange because it was against agency policy to
do so. Foster Care Worker 2 reported the agency workers “have
always been told” to not accept and never ask for anything from
parents or caregivers. Foster Care Worker 2 stated she has never
heard Foster Care Worker 1 ask any caregivers or parents for
money. Foster Care Worker 2 stated the agency would not
approve of or condone a worker taking money from anyone they
work with.
Foster Care Worker 3 was interviewed by phone on 3/27/2025.
She reported she and Foster Care Worker 1 were very close. She
stated they were work partners and sat beside one another in their
office. Foster Care Worker 3 stated she does not know a lot about
the investigation, but she never had any suspicions that Foster
Care Worker 1 was doing anything inappropriate. Foster Care
Worker 3 stated she helped Foster Care Worker 1 a lot with this
case. She stated Parent A was AWOL and had been for several
months. Foster Care Worker 3 went with Foster Care Worker 1 to
Parent A’s home to knock on her door a few times, but there were
no answers. She never heard Foster Care Worker 1 state that
Parent A was in Sault Ste. Marie, but she did hear her tell
Caregiver A she thought Parent A might be in Florida. Foster Care
Worker 3 attended court with Foster Care Worker 1 who reported
she was making attempts to locate Parent A. Foster Care Worker
3 stated Foster Care Worker 1 has a big heart and wanted Parent
A to do well.
5

Foster Care Worker 3 stated the agency is very strict about not
accepting anything from caregivers or parents and the workers
should document if anyone tries to give them anything. She stated
there have been times parents have tried to give her money for
their kids, which she refused and documented. She stated she
has one case in which the parents have repeatedly wanted to give
her money for her child to participate in pageants, but she tells the
parent to give the money directly to the child and Foster Care
Worker 3 will tell the caregiver. Foster Care Worker 3 stated she
has talked to Foster Care Worker 1 about this during her training
period and told Foster Care Worker 1 it would be inappropriate to
take money from caregivers or parents
Caregiver A was interviewed by phone on 3/27/2025. He reported
he has given Foster Care Worker 1 approximately $28,000 since
November of 2024. He stated he started giving Foster Care
Worker 1 money after she stated the agency wanted him to adopt
Youth A, but he wanted to do a guardianship. She said if he
wanted to do a guardianship, he had to pay for it himself. He told
her he was fine with that and started giving her money in the
amounts she told him he needed to. At one point, when Caregiver
A’s daughter, Parent A, was AWOL, Foster Care Worker 1 told
Caregiver A that Parent A had called Foster Care Worker 1 and
told her she thought she was going to die. Foster Care Worker 1
told Caregiver A she found Parent A on the street and called him
asking what she should do. Caregiver A told Foster Care Worker 1
to bring Parent A to the local hospital, and he would pay for her
care. Foster Care Worker 1 told Caregiver A that Parent A did not
want him to come visit her in the condition she was in and that she
could not talk to him. Caregiver A stated he lay in bed crying that
night and worried his daughter was going to die. The following
day, Foster Care Worker 1 called and told Caregiver A Parent A
was doing better and was going to go to a drug rehab facility in
Sault Ste. Marie, but she did not want to talk with Caregiver A at
that time. When Caregiver A called later to speak with Parent A,
Foster Care Worker 1 told him she had already been picked up
and was being transported to the rehab facility. Whenever
Caregiver A asked Foster Care Worker 1 if he could talk to or visit
Parent A, she told him Parent A was in lockdown and was not
allowed to talk to or write anyone. Caregiver A stated Foster Care
Worker 1 told him Parent A could have a private room at the
facility for $2,200 which Caregiver A gave to Foster Care Woker 1.
Foster Care Worker 1 told Caregiver A that Parent A was
progressing in the program and was being enrolled in classes for
which she needed a laptop. Caregiver A paid for the computer as
well as for a tv and clothing for Parent A by giving money to Foster
6

Care Worker 1. He stated, at one point, Foster Care Worker 1 told
Caregiver A that Parent A had gotten into a fight at the facility and
needed 7 stitches in her hand, which Caregiver A gave her money
for. Caregiver A stated he would have paid any amount of money
to save his daughter’s life.
Caregiver A stated Foster Care Worker 1 told him they didn’t want
anyone to know where Parent A was when she was in rehab
because if they did, they would take her parental rights away.
Caregiver A stated he went to court every 3 months during which
Foster Care Worker 1 would say she didn’t know where Parent A
was. During the most recent hearing, the judge told Foster Care
Worker 1 to go to Parent A’s mother’s door and leave papers and
to search for Parent A on social media. After court, Caregiver A
met Foster Care Worker 1 at a library and gave her more money.
Caregiver A stated he went to Parent A’s mother’s home to tell her
not to tell anyone that Parent A was in Sault Ste. Marie. When he
knocked on the door, Parent A answered. She told Caregiver A
she had never been to a rehab facility in Sault Ste. Marie.
Caregiver A was shocked and talked with Parent A about what
Foster Care Worker 1 had been telling him. He learned Parent A
had never been to the hospital, had never been in a fight, and
Foster Care Worker 1 had not bought her a computer, clothes, or
any of the things Foster Care Worker 1 took money from
Caregiver A for.
Caregiver A stated he called Attorney and told her that he had
been giving money to Foster Care Worker 1. He stated he later
met with the police to provide a report. He also provided the
detective with his phone data and messages from Foster Care
Worker 1 telling Caregiver A how much money he needed and
where to meet. He stated he later called Foster Care Worker 1
who told him she needed $460 toward his guardianship case. He
stated the police gave him the money to give Foster Care Worker
1, put a body cam in Caregiver A’s pocket, and gave him a cell
phone to leave open in his truck so officers could hear his
interaction with Foster Care Worker 1. He met Foster Care Worker
1 at a local parking lot and gave her the $460. She took the
money and told him she would need more money for the
guardianship the following Monday. Caregiver A stated he left and
gave the officers their phone and body cam.
Caregiver A stated the week following Foster Care Worker 1’s
arrest, he spoke to Detective and provided his bank account
information so Detective could verify the amounts of money
Caregiver A withdrew to give Foster Care Worker 1. He stated he
7

has not heard from the detective since and has complied with
everything asked of him.
Caregiver A stated he likes Foster Care Worker 1 and that she is
really good person. He stated she had fooled him and if he hadn’t
stopped at Parent A’s mother’s house that day, he would still be
giving her money.
Attorney was interviewed by phone on 4/7/2025. She reported
she was contacted by Caregiver A who reported he had been
giving money to Foster Care Worker 1. She stated she reached
out to law enforcement after which Detective was assigned. She
stated Foster Care Worker A was arrested, but released after no
charges were filed. She stated she was told by Detective he had
documents to review before he could pursue charges.
Detective was interviewed by phone on 4/10/2025. He confirmed
he was investigating allegations that Foster Care Worker 1 asked
for and took money from Caregiver A. He confirmed she was
arrested then released as they had not yet completed their
investigation. He indicated he was confident charges would be
filed; He was in the process of reviewing documentation and
would be completing his report within the next couple of weeks.
Detective followed up with an email on 6/20/2025 stating a warrant
was issued for Foster Care Worker 1 on the charge of larceny by
conversion involving $20,000 or more. He stated the offense
carries a potential penalty of up to 10 years in prison and/or
$15,000 fine.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
• 2/28/2025 Search Warrant for, in part, all electronic
devices, information needed to access the electronic
devices (passwords, encryption information, etc.)
electronically stored communication, as well as all physical
documents related to Foster Care Worker 1 and Youth A.
• Foster Care Worker 1’s Personnel file containing the

requested

o 6/12/2023 Orientation acknowledgment indicating

• 6/20/2025 email from Detective stating an arrest warrant

• 8/26/2025 email from Attorney stating Foster Care Worker
1 has a case pending in 67th District court and a preliminary

• MiCourt Case Search utilizing Foster Care Worker 1’s
name resulting in case 2025-25T01687-FY documenting

o 6/23/2025 felony arraignment, charge of larceny

o 6/23/2025 bond set at $5,000

conference

Analysis A violation is established as Foster Care Worker 1 did not
demonstrate responsible character or suitability to meet the needs
of children and families when being untruthful with Caregiver A
about his daughter’s whereabouts and for being arrested and
9

charged with taking money from Caregiver A under the guise the
money was needed to provide for his daughter’s needs and to
complete the guardianship of his granddaughter.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
Section • (2) The personnel record must contain all the following
Description information before employment may occur:
• (f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a
written evaluation of the convictions that addresses
the nature of the conviction, the length of time since
the conviction, and the relationship of the conviction
to regulated activity.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The chief administrator at the time Foster Care Worker 1 was
hired did not complete a written evaluation of her criminal
convictions, as required.

o 6/12/2023 Orientation acknowledgment indicating

• 6/12/2023 Letter from Former Executive Director indicating
he met with Foster Care Worker 1 on 6/8/2023 to discuss
her background check. The letter stated the scenarios that
led to the incidents were discussed as well as Foster Care
Worker 1’s reaction. The letter stated Foster Care Worker 1
explained she has grown and matured. Former Executive
Director wrote he didn’t see any issues with allowing Foster
Care Worker 1 the opportunity of employment. No details or
assessments were included.
Analysis At the time of Foster Care Worker 1’s hire, the chief administrator
did not complete a written evaluation of the convictions that
addresses the nature of the conviction, the length of time since the
conviction, or the relationship of the conviction to regulated activity
as required.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
